title: Using MObject.become method within a updater results in a loss of reference to the screen object.
body:
Consider the following example:

```
class Example(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        rateOfChange = ValueTracker(1.00)
        def generateText():
            return MathTex(rateOfChange.get_value())
        currentText = generateText()
        self.play(Create(currentText))
        currentText.add_updater(lambda m : m.become(generateText()))
        self.play(rateOfChange.animate.set_value(2.00))
        self.play(currentText.animate.shift(LEFT*3))
        self.wait(1)
```
Here, a value tracker is used to animate between the values 0 and 1.

The text on the screen transitions to a new MathTex object each frame using the ```become``` method.

However, at the end of the update animation, the:

```
currentText.animate.shift(LEFT*3)
```
No longer works because the ```currentText``` variable no longer references the new objects created in each frame.

title: Unable to remove a object on the screen when using an updater
body:
I have the following code:

```
class Example2(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        
        step = ValueTracker(1)
        square = Square()
        circle = Circle()

        self.add(circle)
        self.add(square)

        def circleUpdater(m):
            m.shift(LEFT*0.1)
            self.remove(square)

        circle.add_updater(
            lambda m : circleUpdater(m)
        )

        self.play(step.animate.set_value(0.5))
        self.wait(1)
```

It works by creating a circle that has an updater that should remove the square in each frame. The circle is also shifted to the left each frame. However, the square is not removed in each frame that the updater fires. The square only gets removed at the end of the animate.set_value. 

Details

Manim Community v0.17.1
Windows 11

Proof:

In the video, you can see that it takes one second for the square to remove, which signifies it is being removed after the self.play has finished rather then during.

![ezgif com-gif-maker (4)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41444983/210154829-e8153a9b-d0a3-4f46-8504-cb66ed6a53ba.gif)

title: Small bug: wrong type of "cube" in drawings.py Laptop class.
body:
##Error message:

  File "C:\manim\manimlib\mobject\svg\drawings.py", line 152, in __init__
      body.set_fill(self.shaded_body_color, opacity=1)
  AttributeError: 'Cube' object has no attribute 'set_fill'

## Expected behavior:

Being able to instantiate the class and use it for whatever

## How to reproduce the issue:

```py
import manimlib
class MyScene(manimlib.Scene):
    def construct(self):
        myLaptop = manimlib.Laptop()
```

## How to fix:
In

C:\manim\manimlib\mobject\svg\drawings.py

Import VCube instead of Cube

drawings.py lines [15, 16]
```py
from manimlib.mobject.three_dimensions import Cube #
from manimlib.mobject.three_dimensions import VCube # Bugfix for set_fill() issue. --> Cube is then no longer accessed, so not needed.
```

and in the class Laptop(VGroup)

drawings.py lines [147, 155]
```py
def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(**kwargs)
        body = VCube(side_length=1) # Changed from Cube() to VCube(), fixed the issue for me ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
        for dim, scale_factor in enumerate(self.body_dimensions):
            body.stretch(scale_factor, dim=dim)
        body.set_width(self.width)
        body.set_fill(self.shaded_body_color, opacity=1)
        body.sort(lambda p: p[2])
        body[-1].set_fill(self.body_color)
```

title: Text attribute t2c not working with slices since v1.6.0
body:
### Describe the bug
The `t2c` attribute of `Text` does not work with slices. While it does work by specifying specific words.

**Code**:
```python
from manimlib import *

class Colors(Scene):

    def construct(self):
        one_color = Text('hello', color=BLUE)
        one_color.shift(UP)
        self.play(FadeIn(one_color))

        two_colors = Text('goodbye', t2c={
            '[0:4]': '#cc00aa',
            '[4:7]': '#00bb44'
        })
        self.play(FadeIn(two_colors))

        other_colors = Text('Good bye', t2c={
            'Good': BLUE,
            'bye': RED
        })
        other_colors.shift(DOWN)
        self.play(FadeIn(other_colors))
```

**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
While in `version 1.5.1` the colors of all the texts are displayed correctly

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5247088/193715287-08ce5d1c-3885-4c34-9657-948aba65bee0.mp4

In `versions 1.6.0` and `1.6.1` the central text appears in white

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5247088/193715373-bfed7ac0-f0f6-4cbb-a067-6b0afd21e347.mp4


### Additional context
I'm using Windows 10. Tested on a conda environment using python `3.8.13` and `3.9.13`.

title: `Restore` animation class not functioning
body:
The following code raises an error:
```py
mob = Circle()
mob.save_state()
mob.shift(RIGHT)
self.play(Restore(mob))
```

The error message reads `Trying to restore without having saved`. However, if `Restore(mob)` is replaced with `mob.animate.restore()`, the code works.

I guess this issue has something to do with `Mobject.copy` method, as simply reimplementing `copy` with versions before #1794 (commit [1b009a4](https://github.com/3b1b/manim/pull/1794/commits/1b009a4b035244bd6a0b48bc4dc945fd3b4236ef)) also works.

title: LaTeX not being handled properly when MathTex mobject has single brackets in a string ("{" or "}")
body:
### Description
The MathTex mobject is not being written correctly by the Write method when there is a bracket alone in a string.
A part of the formula is missing or may even be displayed without animation and with some parenthesis caracters missing.
The resulting mobject is not built properly and the submobjects are mixed up.

### Code to reproduce the error
```python
class example(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        eqn = MathTex("u(x)", "=", "{", "y(x)", r"\over", "cos(x)", "}")
        self.wait()
        self.play(Write(eqn))
        self.wait()
```

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71984039/185765731-58a02da5-4217-4596-9198-0755bff535c9.mp4

### Code to show the bad construction of the MathTex mobject
```python
class example(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        eqn = MathTex("u(x)", "=", "{", "y(x)", r"\over", "cos(x)", "}")
        self.wait()
        self.play(Write(eqn))
        self.wait()
        for x in eqn :
            self.play(Indicate(x))
```

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71984039/185765669-fc65a3e5-676e-4d11-8638-a2e7cb644f82.mp4

title: manim in VSCode cause "code unreachable" for reachable codes
body:
### Describe the bug
I'm a developer using VSCode and Pylance to write python codes.
But when I write manim codes in VSC, the python plugin always mark my codes as "code unreachable" and render them as transluscent, which causes trouble to me. I'm sure that all my codes are runnable and are NOT unreachable codes. What's happening and what can I do to fix it?

```
#in sth like MyScene(Scene).construct()
#reachable codes and rendered correctly
...
self.axes = Axes(
			x_range=(-4,4),width=8*1.5,
			y_range=(-2,2),height=4*1.5
		)
axes=self.axes #alias
axes.l1=Tex('1',color=FML_COLOR,).next_to(axes.c2p(1,0),DOWN)
#from the following line on, all my codes till the end of construct(), are recognized as "unreachable codes" and rendered as grey/transluscent.
axes.li=Tex('i',color=FML_COLOR,).next_to(axes.c2p(0,1),LEFT)
axes.ln1=Tex('-1',color=FML_COLOR).next_to(axes.c2p(-1,0),DOWN)
...
```

title: always_redraw rendering only once
body:
### Describe the bug

Testing the `UpdatersExample` I notice that the `Brace` do not rescale following the square as in the example video. 

Reading the `always_redraw` code I could notice that a brand new `mobject` are created inside the updater callback and passed down to `mob.become`. But the `become` method clean the "old mob" updaters and copy the updaters from the "new mob" with has no updater. So, in the end, the redraw updater are deregistered.

Looking at the git log I think the bug was introduced at 0e45b41fea5f22d136f62f4af2e0d892e61a12ce when the `match_updaters` was added to the `become` method.

**Code**:
https://3b1b.github.io/manim/getting_started/example_scenes.html#updatersexample

**Wrong display or Error traceback**:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5621021/170176501-fc19b110-47fa-4184-8082-b9231dfc70b1.mp4

Manim version: master branch at 07a8274cb17db54ce2deb2de28055186e914371c

**Code**:

from manim import *

class fadeout_error(Scene):

        txt = MathTex(r"\text{e}^{\mathbf{i}\pi}+1=0").move_to((s.get_value(),0,0))

title: `ImageMobject` is broken after #1764
body:
### Describe the bug
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
After #1764 (precisely https://github.com/3b1b/manim/pull/1764/commits/8b1f0a8749d91eeda4b674ed156cbc7f8e1e48a8), `ImageMobject` is broken.

**Code**:
<!-- The code you run which reflect the bug. -->
```python
class Code(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        img = ImageMobject("test.png")
        self.add(img)
```

**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
<!-- the wrong display result of the code you run, or the error Traceback -->
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/.../bin/manimgl", line 33, in <module>
    sys.exit(load_entry_point('manimgl', 'console_scripts', 'manimgl')())
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/__main__.py", line 25, in main
    scene.run()
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/scene/scene.py", line 91, in run
    self.construct()
  File "test.py", line 579, in construct
    img = ImageMobject("Tony.png")
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/mobject/types/image_mobject.py", line 27, in __init__
    super().__init__(**kwargs)
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/mobject/mobject.py", line 90, in __init__
    self.init_colors()
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/mobject/mobject.py", line 123, in init_colors
    self.set_color(self.color, self.opacity)
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/mobject/mobject.py", line 1065, in set_color
    self.set_rgba_array_by_color(color, opacity, recurse=False)
  File "/.../manimgl/manimlib/mobject/mobject.py", line 1055, in set_rgba_array_by_color
    if max_len > len(mob.data[name]):
KeyError: 'rgbas'
```

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->
This is because `ImageMobject` don't need data for rgbas so it is not initialized in `init_data` method of ImageMobject. Before that commit, `data['rgbas']` is not read when setting color. But that commit refactored `set_rgba_array_by_color` and read `mob.data[name]` as you can see in the traceback, so it caused a KeyError.

title: Bugs of presenter mode and embed terminal's local variable
body: ### Describe the bug Here are two bugs from #1739 @3b1b ### Bug from https://github.com/3b1b/manim/pull/1739/commits/9a9cc8bdacb7541b7cd4a52ad705abc21f3e27fe The first `scene.wait` won't wait for key press because of https://github.com/3b1b/manim/blob/b3b7d214adff2088f6c75cbc814cbbf8f1a9b4e4/manimlib/scene/scene.py#L66 and https://github.com/3b1b/manim/blob/b3b7d214adff2088f6c75cbc814cbbf8f1a9b4e4/manimlib/scene/scene.py#L497-L500 I think here `self.hold_on_wait` should be equal to `self.presenter_mode` (or `True` because if `self.presenter_mode == False` then `self.hold_on_wait` won't be used in anywhere) ### Bug from https://github.com/3b1b/manim/pull/1739/commits/9df12fcb7d8360e51cd7021d6877ca1a5c31835e The locals() variables in the iPython terminal opened by typing `e` in the interactive mode are not local variables in the users file: So users can't do anything like `play(FadeOut(circle))` (because both `FadeOut` and `circle` are not in the `locals()` dict or `globals()` dict) This issue happend because `embed()` is executed by `scene.on_key_press()` instead of `UserScene.construct()`, so the `local_ns` in `scene.embed()` is read from `scene.on_key_press`'s frame. https://github.com/3b1b/manim/blob/b3b7d214adff2088f6c75cbc814cbbf8f1a9b4e4/manimlib/scene/scene.py#L137-L143 But the whole stack of frame is: ```python > ``` It won't go through the user's code. So I don't know how to fix it elegantly ¯\\\_(ツ)\_/¯

title: Questionable indexing of Tex
body:
### Describe the bug
When I made videos, I used many math equations with specific variables or sub-expressions colored, and noticed there were some bugs in manim dealing with indexing components in `Tex` mobjects. Recently I'm trying to refactor the code of `Tex` class and fix bugs concerning with coloring, so I dive into the source code of `Tex`, only to find that manim just breaks the original tex string with substrings to build new `SingleStringTex` objects, using the lengths of which to do the indexing work. As the formula becomes much more complicated, some issues cannot be handled through the `modify_special_strings` method.

1. Symbols given by the same command, like `\sqrt`, may have different shapes or even different numbers of components making up them.
2. The order between symbols may be swapped from the original tex string such as `\frac`, `\sum`, and super- and subscripts.

When compiling a tex string, each specified pieces of it should be tracked so that the indices of their corresponding components can be found. This, however, may require us to dive right into the nature of how TeX works... I want to look for external tools to finish the "tracking" work. I'm not even sure whether there're approaches to fixing this issue perfectly...

**Code**:
This is just a combination of all messy stuff, so don't care about its actual meaning...
```python
from manimlib import *


TEST_STR = """\\lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\left\\lfloor
\\sqrt{\\frac{1}{n !} \\mathrm{e}^{n} a_{n} + b_{n}^{p}} \\otimes
\\sqrt[n]{\\sum_{m = 0}^{n^{2}} \\tilde{c}_{m \\cdot n}^{b_{n}^{p}
\\cos \\left( \\theta \\right)}} \\right\\rfloor""".replace("\n", " ")


class TestScene(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        tex1 = Tex(
            TEST_STR,
            fill_color=TEAL
        )
        tex1.shift(2 * UP)
        tex2 = Tex(
            TEST_STR,
            tex_to_color_map={"b": LIGHT_PINK, "\\sum": YELLOW},
            fill_color=TEAL
        )
        tex2.shift(2 * DOWN)
        sub_tex = VGroup(*[
            Tex(s, fill_color=BLUE)
            for s in re.split(r"(b|\\sum)", TEST_STR)
        ]).scale(0.8).arrange(RIGHT, buff=0.7)
        self.add(tex1, tex2, sub_tex)

        # Labels of indices for debugging
        self.add(
            # index_labels(tex1[0]),
            # *[index_labels(submob) for submob in tex2],
            # *[index_labels(submob[0]) for submob in sub_tex]
        )
```

I am trying to make a variable length list of updater functions. When I explicitly write out the list, the code works. However, if I try to use list comprehension or just append functions to a list, it only uses the last function added. This might be some Python behavior I am not familiar with?

Here is version 1: This code works with the dots going in different directions.

 %%manim Lambda_Test_1

          t = ValueTracker(0)
          d = np.array([[1, 1, 0],

                      lambda x: x.move_to(d[1] * t.get_value()),

title: Changing the ticking of an axis
body:
### Describe the bug
Starting from the example scene CoordinateSystemExample, you can't change the ticking of an axis correctly. The parameters `x_min`, `x_max` and `x_step` of NumberLine are used in the function `add_ticks()`. This function doesn't work if the NumberLine has been scaled up or down. 

**Code**:
Here's the code I added at the end of the example: (I also linked the whole example code at the end of the bug issue so this post is self-contained).
```
     #self.play(FadeOut(VGroup(axes, dot, h_line, v_line)))

     x_ax = axes.get_x_axis()
     x_ax.x_min = 0
     x_ax.x_max = 1
     x_ax.x_step = 0.1
     x_ax.add_ticks()
```


**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
I expect to see ticks appears at [0.1, 0.2, ..., 0.9] on the Numberline. The ticks appear all over the Numberline at unexpected value.

### Additional context
I think it would be a good idea to create a function called modify_axis_range() or something like that to make it easier to change the ticking of the Numberline. 

Here's the full code of the example.
```
from manimlib import *

waitTime = 0
runt = 0.1

class CoordinateSystemExample(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        axes = Axes(
            # x-axis ranges from -1 to 10, with a default step size of 1
            x_range=(-1, 10),
            # y-axis ranges from -2 to 2 with a step size of 0.5
            y_range=(-2, 2, 0.5),
            # The axes will be stretched so as to match the specified
            # height and width
            height=6,
            width=10,
            # Axes is made of two NumberLine mobjects.  You can specify
            # their configuration with axis_config
            axis_config={
                "stroke_color": GREY_A,
                "stroke_width": 2,
            },
            # Alternatively, you can specify configuration for just one
            # of them, like this.
            y_axis_config={
                "include_tip": False,
            }
        )
        # Keyword arguments of add_coordinate_labels can be used to
        # configure the DecimalNumber mobjects which it creates and
        # adds to the axes
        axes.add_coordinate_labels(
            font_size=20,
            num_decimal_places=1,
        )
        self.add(axes)

        # Axes descends from the CoordinateSystem class, meaning
        # you can call call axes.coords_to_point, abbreviated to
        # axes.c2p, to associate a set of coordinates with a point,
        # like so:
        dot = Dot(color=RED)
        dot.move_to(axes.c2p(0, 0))
        self.play(FadeIn(dot, scale=0.5), run_time=runt)
        self.play(dot.animate.move_to(axes.c2p(3, 2)), run_time=runt)
        self.wait(waitTime)
        self.play(dot.animate.move_to(axes.c2p(5, 0.5)), run_time=runt)
        self.wait(waitTime)

        # Similarly, you can call axes.point_to_coords, or axes.p2c
        # print(axes.p2c(dot.get_center()))

        # We can draw lines from the axes to better mark the coordinates
        # of a given point.
        # Here, the always_redraw command means that on each new frame
        # the lines will be redrawn
        h_line = always_redraw(lambda: axes.get_h_line(dot.get_left()))
        v_line = always_redraw(lambda: axes.get_v_line(dot.get_bottom()))

        self.play(
            ShowCreation(h_line),
            ShowCreation(v_line),
            run_time=runt,
        )
        self.play(dot.animate.move_to(axes.c2p(3, -2)), run_time=runt)
        self.wait(waitTime)
        self.play(dot.animate.move_to(axes.c2p(1, 1)), run_time=runt)
        self.wait(waitTime)

        # If we tie the dot to a particular set of coordinates, notice
        # that as we move the axes around it respects the coordinate
        # system defined by them.
        f_always(dot.move_to, lambda: axes.c2p(1, 1))
        self.play(
            axes.animate.scale(0.75).to_corner(UL),
            run_time=runt,
        )
        self.wait(waitTime)
        #self.play(FadeOut(VGroup(axes, dot, h_line, v_line)))

        x_ax = axes.get_x_axis()
        x_ax.x_min = 0
        x_ax.x_max = 1
        x_ax.x_step = 0.1
        x_ax.add_ticks()

```

        tensordot = TexText("$ \otimes $")

title: ThreeDScene methods not implemented but give no warning
NumberPlane() axis_config.x_min and x_max do not seem to update the axis bounds
body:
Hopefully this is not a bug (I'm still learning to use Manim); but I think it might be worth looking into by a more experienced user.

If I create a NumberPlane defining its axis bounds with x_axis_config, it behaves as expected; changing the axis bounds. On the other hand, if the definition of the axis bounds is made under the axis_config parameter, then it does not update the bounds.

Here's an MWE:

```
class XboundsError(MovingCameraScene):           
    def setup(self):
        MovingCameraScene.setup(self)
    def construct(self):
        self.camera.frame.save_state()


        #This line below creates the grid correctly
        #grid = NumberPlane(x_axis_config={"x_min": -20, "x_max": 20}) 
        #This line below creates the grid **BUT IT IGNORES THE AXIS BOUNDS**
        grid = NumberPlane(axis_config={"x_min": -20, "x_max": 20})

        self.play(Create(grid),run_time=1)
        self.wait(1)
        self.play(self.camera.frame.animate.move_to([5,0,0])) #When creating NumberPlane with axis_config, this camera motion reveals where the plane ends
        self.wait(1)
        self.play(self.camera.frame.animate.move_to([-5,0,0]))
        self.wait(1)

title: Chained animations don't work
body:
### Describe the bug
When running multiple animations in on self.play call, only the last one is executed. 

**Code**:
Minimal code example:
```
class CoordinateSystemExample(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        dot = Dot(color=RED)
        self.play(FadeIn(dot, scale=0.5))

        self.play(
            dot.animate.scale(75),
            dot.animate.to_corner(UL),
            run_time=2,
        )
```


**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
What I get is:
![CoordinateSystemExample](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/426313/113418757-9c905380-93b5-11eb-974d-336339dec97a.png)
What I expect is a a huge dot in the top right corner. 

### Additional context
The CoordinateSystemExample example exhibits the same issue: the axes and the dot get moved to top right corner, but they don't get scaled, like in the video.

title: Incorrect graphing?
body:
### Describe the bug
Manim's [`GraphScene`](https://docs.manim.community/en/v0.1.1/reference/manim.scene.graph_scene.GraphScene.html) output is showing some artefacts in one context: "calculating modulo of 1.0" or `x % 1.0`.

I'll compare it to GeoGebra, because I have a [GeoGebra](https://www.geogebra.org/calculator) tab open, it has a [mod command](https://wiki.geogebra.org/en/Mod_Command) and it shows a different result.

**Code**:
```python
from manim import *
import numpy as np

class PhaseValuePlot(GraphScene):
    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
        GraphScene.__init__(
            self,
            x_min=-3,
            x_max=3,
            num_graph_anchor_points=100,
            y_min=-2.0,
            y_max=2.0,
            graph_origin=ORIGIN,
            axes_color=WHITE,
            x_labeled_nums=range(-3, 3, 1),
            y_axis_label="Phase [p]",
            x_axis_label="Time [T]",
            **kwargs
        )
        self.function_color = BLUE

    def construct(self):
        self.setup_axes()
        func_graph = self.get_graph(lambda t: t % 1.0, x_min=-2, x_max=2, discontinuities=[1], color=self.function_color)
        phase_formula = MathTex(r"p = T \mod 1.0")
        phase_formula.next_to(func_graph, RIGHT + UP)

        self.play(ShowCreation(self.axes))
        self.play(Write(phase_formula))
        self.play(Write(func_graph))
        self.wait(3)
        self.play(FadeOut(func_graph))
        self.play(FadeOut(self.axes))
```

**Expected output**:
GeoGebra shows (I believe) a correct plot.

![](https://i.imgur.com/DzG0M42.png)

**Wrong display**:

There's some "ripple" on the function output I'd like to fix. Also, function output reaches values less than `0`.
Also, I don't mind the vertical lines.

![](https://i.imgur.com/pePUYQm.png)


### Additional context

I am not completely sure it's graphing and not some weird floating point operation, so that is the first thing to check here.

title: Bug in Interactive Mobjects
body:
### Bug
When running `ControlsExample` Scene in ExampleScenes.py, I am getting maximum recursion depth exceeded error.

**Code**:
`ControlsExample` Scene in `example_scenes.py`.

**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
```RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded```

### Analysis
This bug is caused because of the following:
1. `text.add_updater(text_updater)` calls `text_updater` (because add_updater has call_updater default to True)
2. `text_updater` calls `old_text.become(new_text)`
3. `become` calls `align_family`
4. `align_family` calls `add_n_more_submobjects`
5. `add_n_more_submobjects` calls `self.copy()`
6. `copy()` calls `match_updaters`
7. `match_updaters` calls `add updater(text_updater)` on `copy_mobject`
8. `add_updater(text_updater)` calls `text_updater` (because add_updater has call_updater default to True)
9. This takes back to 1. and this continues indefinately

I tried to figure out which commit broke this Scene, and found that before this commit https://github.com/3b1b/manim/commit/d7f3f5ad24b22ed7bc85ee27df03319498fa863f, everything was working fine.
So this bug is caused due to something changed in https://github.com/3b1b/manim/commit/d7f3f5ad24b22ed7bc85ee27df03319498fa863f commit.

title: dvisvgm cannot create svg files in the default temporary storage folder on Windows
body:
### Describe the bug
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
When I run a scene that contains `Tex` and do not make changes to `custom_defaults.yml`, an `OSError` will be thrown, indicating that the svg file cannot be found.
```
OSError: C:\Users\Me\Temp\Tex\1b70addfb3f4902b.svg not Found
```
It may be because my current running directory is in the `D:` drive, and the system default temporary folder is in the `C:` drive. And dvisvgm cannot run across disks.
And when I set `temporary_storage` in `custom_defaults.yml` to a folder in `D:` drive, it can run normally

**Code**:
<!-- The code you run which reflect the bug. -->
```python
class TestTemp(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        tex = Tex("abc")
        self.add(tex)
```
**Wrong display or Error traceback**:
<!-- the wrong display result of the code you run, or the error Traceback -->

<details>
<summary>Traceback</summary>

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "manim.py", line 5, in <module>
    manimlib.main()
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\__init__.py", line 12, in main
    scene.run()
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\scene\scene.py", line 76, in run
    self.construct()
  File "test.py", line 5, in construct
    tex = Tex("abc")
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\mobject\svg\tex_mobject.py", line 167, in __init__      
    super().__init__(full_string, **kwargs)
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\mobject\svg\tex_mobject.py", line 48, in __init__       
    "should_remove_null_curves": True,
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\mobject\svg\svg_mobject.py", line 55, in __init__       
    self.file_path = get_full_vector_image_path(file_name)
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\utils\images.py", line 21, in get_full_vector_image_path
    extensions=[".svg", ".xdv"],
  File "D:\Users\Me\Desktop\manim\manim_shaders\manimlib\utils\file_ops.py", line 48, in find_file
    raise IOError(f"{file_name} not Found")
OSError: C:\Users\Me\AppData\Local\Temp\Tex\1b70addfb3f4902b.svg not Found
```

</details>

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->
dvisvgm version: 2.6.3

If I set the output level of dvisvgm to the highest level in `tex_file_writing.py` and output the executed command, I will see:
```
dvisvgm "C:\Users\Me\AppData\Local\Temp\Tex\1b70addfb3f4902b.dvi" -n -v 7 -o "C:\Users\Me\AppData\Local\Temp\Tex\1b70addfb3f4902b.svg" > nul

pre-processing DVI file (format version 2)
processing page 1
  computing extents based on data set by preview package (version 11.91)
  width=13.905134pt, height=6.944447pt, depth=0pt
  graphic size: 13.905134pt x 6.944447pt (4.887096mm x 2.440694mm)
  WARNING: failed to write output to C:../../../AppData/Local/Temp/Tex/1b70addfb3f4902b.svg
1 of 1 page converted in 1.398 seconds
```
**Note** that even if the output file is specified in the command as `"C:\Users\Me\AppData\Local\Temp\Tex\1b70addfb3f4902b.svg"` (absolute path). But dvisvgm still wants to use a relative path, and the currently running path is under `D:` drive, so dvisvgm specifies the disk to `C:` and sets the output location to `"C:../../../AppData/Local/Temp/Tex/1b70addfb3f4902b.svg"`, which of course will cause errors.

So facing this problem, we should try to solve the problem of dvisvgm (I think it will be more difficult), or change a default temporary storage folder for Windows instead of using the system default `tempfile.gettempdir()`.

title: Conflict between extract_scene.py and scene_file_writer.py causes error while displaying GraphScene
body:
## Description of bug / unexpected behavior
When attempting to display a GraphScene class, the program throws error **'SceneFileWriter' object has no attribute 'movie_file_path'**. After examining log output below, I traced the error to stem from a disagreement between extract_scene.py and scene_file_writer.py, where the former has 'write_to_movie' as True, whereas the latter has it as False.



## Expected behavior
<!-- Add a clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->
/media/videos folder should contain videos of animated graph as file output.


## How to reproduce the issue
<!-- Provide a piece of code illustrating the undesired behavior. -->

# experiments.py
from manimlib.imports import *


class BuildingGraph(GraphScene):

    def __init__(self,**kwargs):
        GraphScene.__init__(self)

    def construct(self):
        #build graph
        self.setup_axes(animate=False)
        graph = self.get_graph(lambda x:x**2,RED) #x^2 graph
        graph_label = self.get_graph_label(graph,label = 'x^{2}')
        graph2 = self.get_graph(lambda x:x**3,PURPLE) #x^3 graph

```
</details>

## Additional comments
<!-- Add further context that you think might be relevant for this issue here. -->

I followed the Traceback messages, and ended up with what I think could be the issue:
In extract_scene.py, the following code from Line 31 is part of the error.
```py
if config["file_writer_config"]["write_to_movie"]:
    file_paths.append(file_writer.get_movie_file_path())
```
Here, a print statement reveals:
```py
print(config["file_writer_config"]["write_to_movie"])
True
```

'file_writer.get_movie_file_path()' calls upon scene_file_writer.py, but there is a conflict here. 
```py
CONFIG = {
        "write_to_movie": False,
        .
        .
        .
}
```
Here, write_to_movie is hardcoded as False, conflicting with the 'True' from before.
Now that write_to_movie is false, it causes this piece of code to not execute, and self.movie_file_path to never be assigned.
```py
if self.write_to_movie:
            if consts.VIDEO_DIR != "":
                movie_dir = guarantee_existence(os.path.join(
                    consts.VIDEO_DIR,
                    module_directory,
                    self.get_resolution_directory(),
                ))
            else:
                movie_dir = guarantee_existence(consts.VIDEO_OUTPUT_DIR)
            self.movie_file_path = os.path.join(
                movie_dir,
                add_extension_if_not_present(
                    scene_name, self.movie_file_extension
                )
            )
```

Which then results in the error when get_movie_file_path is called, and tries to return self.movie_file_path, which was never created.
```py
def get_movie_file_path(self):
    """
    Returns the final path of the written video file.

    Returns
    -------
    str
        The path of the movie file.
    """
    return self.movie_file_path
```

Hard-coding write_to_movie in the CONFIG from scene_file_writer.py causes the program to run as expected, as both programs act upon write_to_movie being True. 
I'm not sure why write_to_movie is forced to False, therefore - shouldn't it change with extract_scene.py?

I also looked into where the 'True' write_to_movie originated from in extract_scene.py, but it appeared to come from:
```py
def main(config):
```
I don't know where this is called, so I couldn't go further.


Is this expected behaviour? Since scene_file_writer.py includes a message about not needing to edit it, I imagine I shouldn't need to do so to create the animation; if it is intended, my apologies, and I'd wonder if it should be changed to be based upon extract_scene.py.

Thanks in advance!

title: Trouble with setup_axes( )
body:
### Describe the error
I'm new using Manim and I tried to animate a basic graph plot. When I run the code is displayed a error in self.setup_axes(). It is related with "tick_marks". What should I do?

### Code and Error
**Code**:
from manimlib.imports import *
import numpy as np 


class Plot2yLabelNumbers(GraphScene):
    CONFIG = {
        "y_min": 0,
        "y_max": 100,
        "y_axis_config": {"tick_frequency": 10},
        "y_labeled_nums": np.arange(0, 100, 10)
    }

title: Transform VGroup to TexMobject
body:
I'm new to manim and I want to transform a VGroup made up of several TexMobject to a single Tex
Mobject, however something unexpected happened.

This is my code

```
#!/usr/bin/env python

from big_ol_pile_of_manim_imports import *

class SumDC(Scene):
    def construct(self):
        list1 = TexMobject(r"1+2+3+4+\cdots +n=?")
        list2 = TexMobject(r"a_1+a_2+a_3+a_4+\cdots +a_n=?")
        desc = TexMobject(r"a_{n+1}-a_n=d")
        
        min1 = TexMobject(r"a_2-a_1=d")
        min1.shift(2 * UP)
        min2 = TexMobject(r"a_3-a_2=d")
        min2.next_to(min1, DOWN)
        min3 = TexMobject(r"a_4-a_3=d")
        min3.next_to(min2, DOWN)
        min4 = TexMobject(r"\cdots")
        min4.next_to(min3, DOWN)
        min5 = TexMobject(r"a_n-a_{n-1}=d")
        min5.next_to(min4, DOWN)
        minn = VGroup(min1, min2, min3, min4, min5)
        
        summ = TexMobject(r"a_n-a_1=\left( n-1 \right) d") 
        summ2 = TexMobject(r"a_n=a_1+\left( n-1 \right) d")
        
        self.play(Write(list1))
        self.wait(2)
        self.play(Transform(list1, list2))
        self.wait(2)
        self.play(ApplyMethod(list1.shift, 3 * UP))
        self.play(Write(minn))
        self.wait(2)
        self.play(Transform(minn, summ))
        self.wait(2)
        self.play(Transform(minn, summ2))
```

After transforming the image looks like this

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10304206/52052373-12f45980-2591-11e9-8876-04d526f71461.png)

How can I solve the problem? Thank you.
